boat.name: Capella
boat.full_description:
Capella is a good representative of the boats that David Hillyard was building at Littlehampton before WWII. The Hillyard yard was at that time pioneering mass production of yachts to standard designs. The boats were all carvel built, long keeled with mostly canoe sterns and ranged in size from 2.5 to 11 tons.

Capella was built in 1937 and cost her owner in the region of £475. It is believed that she was originally named 'If' but first appears in Lloyds yacht list as Capella the following year. It appears that Capella was kept by her first owner until 1960 and was berthed somewhere in Belfast.

Since 1960 Capella changed ownership several times and has been kept variously on the Solent, at Fleetwod and in Falmouth. She has purportedly done a circumnavigation of Britain.

Much of the original interior has alas been removed or altered but she retains something the atmosphere of a 1930s cruising yacht.
boat.construction_details:
Oak backbone, sawn oak frames at 30in spacing with three steamed timbers between, pitchpine planking, elm garboards, all bronze and copper fastened. Cast iron outside ballast keel of about three tons and about one and a half tons of inside lead ballast.
Deck is of painted ply over the original tongue and groove boarding on sawn oak beams. Spars of douglas fir, made new by Hillyards in 2005.
boat.short_description: Capella is a 9 ton Hillyard built in Littlehampton. She has a canoe sterned carvel built hull constructed of pitch pine on oak frames and backbone. Her bright work is a mixture of mahogany and teak.
